items.title: More Canadians have a family doctor, but 'concerning gaps' found
items.summary_auto: More Canadians have a family doctor or nurse practitioner compared with three years ago, though satisfaction remains low, a comprehensive new survey suggests.

items.title: Drugs, inter-governmental relations and wildfires dominate Sask. fall sitting
items.summary_auto: Premier Scott Moe called this sitting a success, but his government has faced criticism on health care and wildfire response.

items.title: Flying Air Transat? Here's what customers need to know as strike looms
items.summary_auto: Air Transat announced on Sunday it will gradually shut down operations over the next three days in response to a 72-hour strike mandate issued by the union representing its 750 pilots. Here's what travellers need to know.

items.title: Fire departments battle blaze at fish plant in Cumberland County
items.summary_auto: Emergency services are at the scene of a blaze at Aquashell Holdings Inc. in Wallace, N.S.

items.title: Canada unveils 27-player world junior training camp roster, led by NHL prospect Gavin McKenna
items.summary_auto: Gavin McKenna headlines the 27 players Hockey Canada has invited to its world junior training camp ahead of the 2026 tournament in Minnesota.

items.title: Kugaaruk, Nunavut, declares state of emergency over failure at water treatment plant
items.summary_auto: In a news release Sunday, the Nunavut Emergency Management (NEM) said the hamlet declared a local state of emergency after sea water infiltrated the water treatment plant leaving the community without a reliable source of potable water.

items.title: Air Transat, pilots' union say 'progress' being made in talks as strike deadline looms
items.summary_auto: Air Transat says that "progress has been made" in negotiations with the union representing its pilots, just a day after the Air Line Pilots Association, Intl. issued a 72-hour strike notice.

items.title: Anti-hate bill stalled after Fraser’s office brokered deal without PMO approval: sources
items.summary_auto: The future of the federal government’s anti-hate Bill C-9 is unclear, after Justice Minister Sean Fraser’s office brokered a deal with the Bloc Québécois without getting it approved by the Prime Minister’s Office, sources tell CBC News.

items.title: Liberals to open new fast track to permanent residency for 5,000 foreign doctors
items.summary_auto: The federal government is promising to open up permanent residency for foreign doctors currently working in Canada as temporary foreign residents in order to tackle the doctor shortage across the country.

items.title: 'She froze to death,' says grandson of woman found dead outside Laval seniors' residence
items.summary_auto: An 88-year-old woman has died after being found outside a seniors' residence in Laval early this morning. Temperatures dropped to -18 C early Monday morning, according to Environment Canada.

items.title: Criminal group linked to Ontario hospital shooting, Quebec homicide dismantled, police say
items.summary_auto: A criminal network allegedly responsible for a host of violent crimes in both Ontario and Quebec has been dismantled after a multi-jurisdictional investigation that resulted in 13 arrests and over 150 charges laid, police representatives announced Monday at a news conference at York Regional Police headquarters.

items.title: Japan downgrades tsunami warning, but warns of potential for stronger quakes in coming days
Paramount Skydance makes $108B US hostile bid for Warner Bros. Discovery after Netflix move
items.summary_auto: Paramount Skydance on Monday launched a hostile bid worth $108.4 billion US for Warner Bros Discovery, throwing a wrench into the deal with Netflix in a last-ditch effort to create a media powerhouse that would challenge the dominance of the streaming giant.

items.title: One Battle After Another leads Golden Globe nominations, Canadians Catherine O'Hara and Martin Short nominated
items.summary_auto: One Battle After Another collected nine nominations for the 83rd Golden Globes, while Sentimental Value has eight, Sinners seven, and Hamnet six. Performances by stars of The White Lotus and Adolescence helped those films rack up a number of nominations on the TV side, too.

items.title: Hate crime unit investigating removal of Jewish prayer scrolls from Toronto doorways
items.summary_auto: About 20 mezuzahs were reportedly taken over the weekend from outside multiple units of a Toronto Seniors Housing Corporation building, Toronto police say.

items.title: Could you outrun the train? Toronto's new LRT takes 55 minutes to cover 10.3 km
items.summary_auto: Northwest Toronto's newly-opened light-rail transit (LRT) line is getting its first taste of rush hour Monday — but it doesn't appear to be rushing.

items.title: Could you outrun the train? Finch LRT takes 55 minutes to cover 10.3 km route
items.summary_auto: Northwest Toronto's newly-opened light-rail transit (LRT) line is getting its first taste of rush hour Monday — but it doesn't appear to be rushing.

items.title: Ukraine's Zelenskyy says a revised peace plan will be shared with U.S. on Tuesday
items.summary_auto: Ukraine will share a revised peace plan with the U.S. on Tuesday aimed at ending Russia's war, after talks in London between President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and the leaders of France,  Germany and Britain.

items.title: NHL Heritage Classic's 2026 return to Winnipeg will be 'great for the city,' fans say
items.summary_auto: The NHL's Heritage Classic is returning to Winnipeg next year and some local sports fans — including a former Jets goalie — say the outdoor hockey spectacle will draw a lot of positive attention to the city.

items.title: Northern Ontario woman who left abuser starts program to help survivors restart their lives
items.summary_auto: Caisse Alliance credit union in North Bay, Ont., offers a unique program to help intimate partner violence survivors rebuild their financial lives, thanks to an employee who restarted her life from zero after leaving an abusive partner.

items.title: Thailand launches airstrikes along border with Cambodia after deadly clashes
items.summary_auto: Thailand launched airstrikes along the disputed border with Cambodia on Monday as both sides accused the other of breaking a ceasefire that halted fighting earlier this year.

items.title: Workshops aim to change 'boys will be boys' culture in construction sector
items.summary_auto: The facilitator of the course says deeply rooted masculine norms in male-dominated industries such as construction can affect the health of workers.

items.title: Dramatic price increases for Canadians visiting U.S. national parks could benefit Maritimes
items.summary_auto: Next year, it will be incredibly more expensive for foreign residents to visit American national parks.

items.title: Northern Ontario jails among the most overcrowded in the province, new data shows
items.summary_auto: Jails in northern Ontario are facing some of the worst overcrowding pressures in the province, with population data showing dramatic increases since 2019. Frontline workers and inmates are warning the conditions inside many facilities are increasingly unsafe.

items.title: Chinese ex-spy opens up about targeting dissident who died mysteriously in B.C.
As fraud in Ontario continues to climb, police are laying fewer charges — and courts are tossing the majority
items.summary_auto: CBC News reviewed the latest three years of fraud statistics released since its investigative series The Cost of Fraud revealed that only a fraction of fraud cases were making it through Ontario’s justice system a few years ago. The new numbers from Statistics Canada show the problem has only gotten worse, and have some experts pointing to alternative solutions to stem the flow of fraud.

items.title: Majority of Ontario fraud cases tossed since 2020 due to limited resources: Crowns’ association
items.summary_auto: CBC News reviewed the latest three years of fraud statistics released since its investigative series The Cost of Fraud revealed that only a fraction of fraud cases were making it through Ontario’s justice system a few years ago. The new numbers from Statistics Canada show the problem has only gotten worse, and have some experts pointing to alternative solutions to stem the flow of fraud.

items.title: Ontario jails set to hit overcrowding record as bail reform looms, data shows
items.summary_auto: Ontario jails are heading toward a record year for overcrowding, remand populations and lockdowns just as politicians debate bail reforms that could lead to a further influx of accused behind bars, data analyzed by CBC News reveals.

items.title: A Chinese dissident died suddenly in B.C. This ex-spy who snooped on him says it may not have been an accident
items.summary_auto: A former spy for China's security services has provided thousands of text and voice messages, as well as financial documents, to journalists. Among the records: instructions from his bosses to snoop on an artist who fled to Canada.

items.title: Bill 2 puts Montreal clinic serving sexual assault victims at risk of closure
items.summary_auto: A family clinic in downtown Montreal that treats over 10,000 patients could close its doors due to Bill 2, a controversial law that ties doctors' salaries to key performance indicators. Dr. Andrée Vincent says Clinique Medic Elle, which also serves as a centre for victims of sexual assault, could lose some of its doctors. She and her colleagues are already receiving job offers from outside the province.

items.title: Why Jeff Kinney draws from his childhood to create the smash 'Wimpy Kid' series
items.summary_auto: With more than "300 million copies sold," American creator Jeff Kinney's cheeky Diary of a Wimpy Kid series is a huge hit. He stopped by The Next Chapter to discuss the series and the latest book, Partypooper.

items.title: #TheMoment students reunited after losing their N.L. school to wildfires
items.summary_auto: Jackie King, Jace Hogan and Allison Slade tell The National about the moment students from Cabot Academy in Conception Bay, N.L., reunited for the holidays after their school burned down in the summer.

items.title: Trump lauds 'good relationship' with Carney but won't say if they'll restart trade talks
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump spoke highly of Canada on Sunday. But when asked if he would restart trade talks with his northern neighbour, he replied with a vague, "We'll see."

items.title: Donald Trump hosting Kennedy Center Honors recognizing Stallone, Kiss, Gaynor and others
